body: In vim, when I suspend with ctrl+z, change something, and then come back, vim will offer me options about reloading files. Neovim simply does not; I have to do :e to reload a file. Is this a bug?

comment_data.body:
I believe this is due to the removal of the `+clientserver` feature. As a workaround, you can add the following to your .nvimrc :

```
autocmd BufEnter,FocusGained * checktime
```

hmm

ctrl+z implementation was moved to the UI layer so it probably has something to do with that
I bissected it out today to this commit: e0e41b30c61922e099a067ac5c137e745699a1aa, but I don't have experience in the neovim codebase, so I cannot help much more.
Any updates on this? This is pretty unexpected and inconvenient.

I have settings in my vimrc now, which are solving this - actually going quite a ways beyond solving it, I now have automatic file reloading of unchanged files, and it warns me about changed ones. I copied this from misc plugins I found googling for automatic swap file control and stuff. I think some of it is from tim pope's vimrc, and some of it is from the autoswap plugin.

from tim pope's, iirc:
- file changed in buffer, but not on disk: allocate a swapfile for it
- file not changed in buffer: remove swap file, so that if vim is killed it doesn't leave one lying around (and allows multiple editing, which with the above rules, I'm fine with)

from some stackoverflow or other:
- file changed on disk, but not in buffer: load it
- file changed on disk and in buffer: warn user, ask what to do

edited from autoswap plugin:
- opening file that has changed swapfile, and file is not newer: ask the user, as normal.
- opening file that has changed swapfile, and file is newer: swapfile has already been abandoned, delete it

``` Viml
augroup AutoSwap
        autocmd!
        autocmd SwapExists *  call AS_HandleSwapfile(expand('<afile>:p'), v:swapname)
augroup END

function! AS_HandleSwapfile (filename, swapname)
        " if swapfile is older than file itself, just get rid of it
        if getftime(v:swapname) < getftime(a:filename)
                call delete(v:swapname)
                let v:swapchoice = 'e'
        endif
endfunction
autocmd CursorHold,BufWritePost,BufReadPost,BufLeave *
  \ if isdirectory(expand("<amatch>:h")) | let &swapfile = &modified | endif

augroup checktime
    au!
    if !has("gui_running")
        "silent! necessary otherwise throws errors when using command
        "line window.
        autocmd BufEnter,CursorHold,CursorHoldI,CursorMoved,CursorMovedI,FocusGained,BufEnter,FocusLost,WinLeave * checktime
    endif
augroup END
```

all of that said, if I remember correctly, Grimy's suggestion was sort-of-working for me. The autocmd I have now, which responds to everything and its dog, is quite a bit more reliable. Would like one that does it for _every_ window.
@lahwran I have the same issue. Your solution works very well for me. Thank you very much!

> - file not changed in buffer: remove swap file, so that if vim is killed it doesn't leave one lying around (and allows multiple editing, which with the above rules, I'm fine with)

Perhaps that should be the built-in behavior...

It's not the built in behaviour right now because by leaving a swap file, it effectively locks it from other vim instances, thereby preventing two vim instances getting out of sync. The settings I have make it impossible to get out of sync a different way - by checking very frequently. (though annoyingly, still only when a particular vim window is focused; if I have two files open next to each other, it only warns me about the one I'm focused on.)
That said, I'd love for my approach to become a sanctioned and thoroughly tested default, unlike my 20 minute hack.

Oh right, forgot about that use-case. 

The OP issue here would largely be addressed by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1380, though I suppose this should stay open in case we find a way to achieve it more directly. 

Also related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1455.

I'm not presented an option to Load a file if I call `:checktime`. It loads it without confirmation that I want that. In Vim8, presents me a number of options, which I'd like because I don't always want to load what's on disk.
@arsenerei Most likely this is because we set 'autoread' by default. Please read `:help nvim-defaults`.
@justinmk Awesome! I just checked and that's all it was. Thanks!

So confused.  I've tried a number of workarounds, including comment 2.  No effect at all.

Can someone summarize the status of this four year old bug?  I'm not sure what to do.

10+ hours of debugging eslint in coc-eslint, found that neovim doesn't work in a sane way, and its extremely unorthodox behavior isn't disclosed somewhere easily accessible. 😦

Thumbs down for current behavior 👎👎👎

Update the file if I just wrote it, I can't see any sane reason not to update what I'm looking at after it's updated. Vim surely has a prompt to ask, so what does neovim do in regards to updating the buffer on `:write`? Does Neovim completely ignore this behavior (saved a buffer, let's look at updated things) and doesn't prompt as vim does?... I can't really comprehend why. This behavior tickles my brain in a bad way, there's no sane reason not to update the buffer when it's updated, or at least disclose how this behavior differs from how vim actually works...
That's a long-standing feature request, actively being worked on in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/12593

@MathiasKandelborg, this is how neovim behaves currently:
with `set autoread`: If a change is detected in the file being displayed in the current buffer, and the buffer has no changes, `:checktime` causes the file to be reloaded without a prompt. However, if the buffer does has some changes, you will see a prompt asking you how to proceed, i.e., overwrite the current file or update.
with `set noautoread`: If a change is detected in the file being displayed in the current buffer, `:checktime` creates a prompt and asks you how to proceed.

This I think should be the default in vim too. The problem with this approach is of course that you would have to execute `:checktime` or `:e` for neovim to check for changes, or else you won't know what happened until you hit `:w`. However things are changing now :)

As for checking changed files on suspend/resume, PR #12531 does that. It already has been merged to the codebase, but you would have to use the latest [`0.5.0` release](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/) to get it. (Or if you want, you can build it from master ;)

For automatically detecting file changes and notifying users about it, we've worked on #12593, and as @teto said, we need feedback on that PR. So if you want to, and you have the time for it, you could try building neovim with that PR, and report any bugs that you come across on that PR itself, or in a new issue.

**PS:** By default, neovim has `autoread` set.

So... maybe I'm missing something. @BK1603 thats a great message you wrote there, but for me I feel like something is weird.

I have `autoread` on by default (its not explicitly configured in my init.lua)

Say I have `package.json` open, i switch to terminal and `pnpm install typescript` and go back to package.json... it's still not updated.

Shouldn't `autoread` mead that as long as I haven't changed the file it will automatically update?

As of 0.11.1, I found there's more to this. It sure behaves as described if you never leave terminal window:

```
nvim --clean test
:set noautoread
^Z
echo overwritten > test
fg
(no reload prompt at this point)
```

..._but_ the moment terminal window gets focused again, I immediately get W11 with prompt to `[O]K, (L)oad File` etc. This behaviour is observed with at least rxvt-unicode and alacritty.
@vthriller because 'autoread' was enhanced since this issue was first created.

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: suspend/resume: check changed files
